page.title: 08LOCAL HISTORY OF HALWELL
page.content: The stone-walled Iron Age hill fort of Stanborough Camp lies 1 1/2kms.s from Halwell,220m above sea level. It encloses 3 acres and commands a wide view of coast and countryside-a good defence position. In 1799 it was excavated and a perfect kist-vaen was found. Remains of other earthworks are nearby. Saxons used the Camp as a fort against raiding Danes. Saxon name-Stonebarrow. Halwell was one of 4 Burghs set up by King Alfred in late 9th Century-Saxon name Halgewell. Both Halwell and Moreleigh are mentioned in the Domesday Book. St. Leonard's Church, Halwell was built in the late 15th Century. Vicarage built 1850. School, built 1839,catered for up to 70 children from Halwell and Moreleigh - closed 1963.
